prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Effect of Prior Rulings Upon Remand

para.paratext: When remand is ordered, the cases are returned to the districts where they were pending at the time of transfer by the Panel. The assigned judge in that district becomes a “successor” judge to the transferee judge. The rulings made in the case to that date remain in effect and binding upon the parties. A question often arises as to whether the successor judge has any latitude to revisit any of the transferee court's rulings. As is often the case, a bright-line rule is hard to draw on this question. This situation can best be viewed as a subset of all the situations in which one federal judge takes over a case from another. The general rules are not surprising: deference to the decisions reached by the prior judge and jurisdiction or authority to modify those rulings. This is particularly true for rulings which the transferee court could have itself modified.

Courts have reached apparently inconsistent results on the question of whether (or when) the successor judge can change prior rulings. Although some courts have concluded that the transferee's rulings cannot be vacated,[1] the better rule is that the court can alter, or even vacate, earlier rulings so long as there is a good reason to do so.[2] The Manual for Complex Litigation observes the appropriate balance:

Although the transferor judge has the power to vacate or modify rulings made by the transferee judge, subject to comity and “law of the case” considerations, doing so in the absence of a significant change of circumstances would frustrate the purposes of centralized pretrial proceedings.[3]
The law of the case doctrine helps establish the outlines of rulings that cannot be revisited, such as prior rulings that have been reviewed and affirmed on appeal.[4]

The role of the law of the case doctrine in answering this question received substantial clarification with a pair of decisions in 2009. In In re Ford Motor Co.,[5] the court considered a petition for mandamus to review a decision by a court on remand from MDL proceedings to revisit a decision by the transferee court that declined to dismiss a case on forum nonconveniens grounds. The court embraced the law of the case approach to resolve this issue, stating:

Under the law of the case doctrine and general principles of comity, a successor judge has the same discretion to reconsider an order as would the first judge, but should not overrule the earlier judge's order or judgment merely because the later judge might have decided matters differently.[6]

Applying the doctrine to the decisions in this case, the court found that both the MDL transferee court and the court on remand erred in not applying the forum nonconveniens doctrine. This decision underscores the flexibility of the law of the case doctrine, combining as it does both deference to prior rulings and the possibility of changing prior orders in exceptional circumstances.

In In re Pharmacy Benefits Managers Antitrust Litigation,[7] the Third Circuit applied the law of the case doctrine to review a transferee court's decisions vacating orders of the transferor court enforcing arbitration agreements between certain of the parties. The court concluded the law of the case doctrine required deference to prior decisions of transferor court on this legal question.[8]
